10/10/17 update: I've made some minor additions to my review to account for new features of the game.

I love this game.  That said, there are some things you should know before you buy it, or else you set yourself up for disappointment.  Most of the negative reviews are from people who didn't know these things before they purchased the game.  That just means the game wasn't meant for them, not that there's anything wrong with the game.  

First, and most importantly, this game does not hold your hand and guide you through how to play.  Exploration and discovery are part of the game by design.  You get a few popup messages explaining some basic concepts, but then you're on your own.  Plan on spending a healthy amount of time on the Wurmpedia looking up how things work, or you will find yourself disappointed and frustrated.  Alternatively, if you like a challenge, it's possible to discover how things work on your own by trial and error, but not many people can do that.  (10/10/17 Update: This also adds to the feeling of accomplishment when you finally build up your settlement as you want it.)

Second, the graphics are not visually impressive.  Some of the graphics are from as long ago as 2006.  They serve a function, and that's it.  If you buy this game expecting AAA modern graphics, you will be disappointed.  Don't expect much from the graphics.  (10/10/17 Update: There has been a graphical upgrade recently, but it's still far from AAA graphics.)

Third, this game is *deep* and can be overwhelming for some.  If you get the chance, take a look at the Skills window and browse through the list.  (10/10/17 Update: There are over one hundred of them.)  Every one of those skills is implemented into the game and affects what you can do in it.  There are also a few actions that don't have an associated skill.  If I haven't convinced you to devote time to browsing the Wurmpedia already, this is a very good reason to do that.

Finally, this game is about survival in a medieval fantasy setting, not about action.  Don't expect much from combat.  Combat is pretty much just targeting something and just making sure you're the right distance from the target to effectively fight.  Instead, enter the game with the expectation that you'll have to "work" towards building your home and training hard enough to put up a fight against hungry spiders, and that the game will reward you by allowing you to make your permanent mark on the game world.  

Your actions have lasting impact in Wurm.  Long after you stop playing on a public server and the buildings you constructed start to crumble, other players will be able to explore the ruins of your settlement and discover what you did there.  If you play on a server that has been around long enough, you can do the same, and it's pretty fun.  (10/10/17 Update: The upcoming Archaeology and Restoration skills will enhance this feature once they make it into the game.)

If you're still wondering whether this is the game for you, just try out the MMO version of this game, Wurm Online.  It's free to play, if you don't mind the level 20 skill cap, or you can pay to go premium, which unlocks higher skill levels.  Wurm Unlimited is essentially an official private server for Wurm Online, so if you find that you like Wurm Online, but either can't afford to spend money each month on premium and deed upkeep, or don't have the time to invest regularly into it, then Wurm Unlimited was made for you.

I know I don't have many hours on Wurm but I figure it's a good enough time as any to write a review for it based on what I have experienced so far.  Apparently, Wurm Unlimited was a game created ages ago and built on a platform that sort of resembled something of an online MMO version of MineCraft. When you first launch Wurm, you're greeted with a sort of generic server selection screen.  These servers are the "free" servers that exist out there on the internet. Once I found my server (Valoria), I was greeted promptly by the several dozen people playing there (I think about 30 when I logged on) and I slowly started exploring the landscape.  I knew going into this that Wurm would be complicated, confusing, and hectic - I wasn't entirely sure how crazy until much later.  My best honest impression of the game is that it’s a cross between an old school MUD, EverQuest, and Minecraft sort of rolled into one.

I knew I had to get something to eat and get near some water, so I started exploring.  I started botanizing the fields and foraging for food.  After I had secured some potatoes, rice, and a belly full of water, I explored.  I just…wandered.  I stumbled upon a village whose members cautiously greeted me and welcomed me to join them and the rest is history.   Within a few hours I felt like a member of the community, a valued member of the server – I was doing things and learning and I had tasks and adventures ahead of me.

But…server stuff aside, let’s talk a little bit about the game itself:  I know I said it's like Minecraft, but...it's also not.  It's complicated.  This is by far the most complex, most complicated crafting sandbox game that I have ever experienced.  There are over 130+ skills, and each skill directly relates to something else.   It’s very deep and very, very complex.  But, that’s not a bad thing.

The best way I can explain this is by using an example that I experienced first-hand within the game.  One of my new friends was telling me that I should work on making some of my own tools so that I could perform all of the various tasks around the village.  Tools like rakes, brushes, carving knives, files, hammers, etc.  You know…tools!

Wurm has an interesting crafting menu where you can search and find the items you want to make, and it tells you what you need to make them…and the sub components, and then it tells you what you need to make those and so forth.   I wanted to make an iron file.  This would be a useful tool for improving the quality of my other tools and objects.  So I went to our village’s storage area and brought up the crafting window.

The file requires a handle, and a file blade.  Okay, easy enough.  The handle requires a shaft, a shaft is made from a log, and a log is cut from a tree.  Grab a log, make a shaft, spin it into a handle …done.

Then, the file blade.  The file blade requires a lump of iron and must be forged into a file blade.  Grab a lump of iron, put it on the anvil.  Uh oh…needs to be glowing hot.  Light the forge, put the lump in the forge, finally the lump is glowing red hot.  Forge the lump into the file blade.   Try to fasten the blade to the handle, uh oh, I waited too long and it’s cooled.  Better toss it back in the forge.   Okay, blade is glowing hot, now I can forge the file.   Done!  Then, I started looking at ways to improve my file.  Polish it with a pelt, hammer on it with a hammer, then…toss it back in the forge, hammer more iron into it, quench it in water to temper it, polish it again… etc, etc.

You get the idea.  Everything in Wurm is vastly complex and complicated, but it makes you feel like you’ve actually achieved something when you finish it.  Even though I only spent about 45-60 minutes at the forge in the game making tools, I actually walked away chuckling to myself about how it’s the closest thing to realistic I’ll get for forging something in a game.

There are, of course, some odd things – negative things that would be impossible for me to ignore.  The music gets on my nerves (easily disabled).   Sometimes the camera makes me nuts.  I would LOVE to drop it into 3rd person view for a few minutes, just while I’m riding around doing menial tasks or exploring.  I know there is an "over-the-shoulder" third person view, but it's not useful at all and your toon blocks 3/4ths of the screen.   I like to play in 1st person, but I like to watch my toon do things when I am just standing in fields harvesting crops, etc.

Another thing that only slightly annoys me is the running speed/movement speed/stamina drain.  You have a stamina bar that you use to perform actions.  You can get stronger, and better, but you can't seem to get faster.  You can't sprint, or run, or expend your stamina for a quick burst of speed (at least I don't think you can, lol).

The skill grind is real, and it’s something that most people that play Wurm will tell you about.  Patience is the name of the game when it comes to playing Wurm and if you don’t have patience it’s not the game for you.  For example.  You can get to 100 in each skill.  I am our village's farmer.  I've farmed over thousands of squares of fields and tended fields and harvested, re-planted, farmed, tended, and harvested again.  My farming skill is only at 28.  It levels slowly.  That doesn't mean you can't do what you want to do, it just means you might be producing lower quality or less quantity than you'd like.

This game is for crafters.  It’s for visionaries.  It’s for people who like to relax after work with a calming zen garden type game where they can relax, brush down their cows, milk them, and make cheese from the milk.  This is the game for people who like to make something out of nothing.  Erect a castle, dig a canal, or run a farm.  It’s like a medieval village simulator.  Play by yourself, play with friends, play as part of a community like Valoria – but if you enjoy crafting sandbox games, I recommend this.  You won’t find super high stakes action here.

Wurm Unlimited was cut loose with some sweet-sounding words and some unfulfilled promises for cleaner mod support, and then just left to drift. I don't have an insider at Code Club, so I have only to speculate as to their reasoning, but what makes sense to me is this: Wurm Unlimited was released as a way to draw people to come try Wurm Online, and they never expected it to be a viable product of its own, and grow its own communities... but it did. I might have gotten to this game quite late, but believe me when I say it's still completely amazing. Despite having started in development 15 years ago as Wurm Online (2003!), this game still receives content updates and overhauls - and the amount of work and love poured into it really shows in its quality. 

This is the absolute best sandbox style game I have ever played, without exaggeration. While its UI is clunky and the game is overwhleming to start, both of these aspects stem from the sheer amount of choice available to you. With complete access to terraforming and over 100 types of skills to do everything you could want - including combat, carpentry, masonry, house-building, farming, animal breeding, tailoring, wine-making, and even bee-keeping - you are completely let free to create your own life in-game. With the sheer number of things to do and goals to set for yourself, each player will have a different experience custom-tailored to their desires, limited more by imagination than ability.

Things in Wurm take time. Time to hone your skills, time to craft, time to complete your goals. Nothing is handed out for free, but instead by your own efforts. This time however, isn't in the form of waiting around - it is through laborious process. Making a cart to be dragged by horses requires assembling planks and wooden shafts to make wheels, putting those wheels onto an axle, and then attaching that to the body of a cart. Everything is done piecemeal, following the natural steps to create something in real life. Even a bed in Wurm takes time to put together: a bed frame, a footboard and headboard (all built from their requisite parts), some sheets and some furs. This isn't like Minecraft, where you can punch a few sheep and a tree and have a bed in minutes; this is a game for when you want to feel like you've accomplished something by working with your hands.

And by hell will you feel those accomplishments. Something that seems so easy in other sandbox games - like building a house - becomes a real task in Wurm. A small, basic house will take you at least an hour or two to put together as you build walls, floors, windows, doors, and a roof. Later on, you'll want to build a bigger house - deciding to put together something with multiple floors, higher ceilings, and more square footage will have you spending multiple days to piece it together. 

Wurm turns tedium into adventure - each step along the way feels like progress instead of grinding. Add that to being in a living, breathing server with other players also shaping the world, and you'll find yourself meeting neighbors, making friends, trading goods and services, exploring together, and lending a helping hand. Even I, who assumed I would play solo and live the life of a hermit, ended up warming up to an extremely friendly community in a tight-knit server, happy to ask questions and give advice.

Seeing as Wurm Unlimited works on a buy-to-play model (as opposed to the subscription service of the Wurm Online MMO), it is more worthy of a purchase than ever before. Most servers on Wurm Unlimited have been running for multiple years, making them just as persistent as an MMO server. If you're looking for a place to start, the Otherlands server cluster is a great place - not too crowded, friendly, and run by a well-respected modder of the game. It's a perfect time as any to start a second life in Wurm!

Wurm Unlimited is one of those gems that's not for everybody.  I had mixed feelings about giving this game a thumbs up or down, but only because of it's price tag.  I'll get to that a bit later though.

First thing's first.  Going into this game I knew to expect a few things.  This game is from the early 2000's, which means the graphics were going to be severly dated by todays standards.  It also started out as an MMO, which means that running it single-player might not be a very good experience.  I also knew this game wasn't for the faint of heart.  It's not your typical survival game, and it doesn't pull it's punches.  This was quite evident when I first entered the world, spawning almost direcly on top of a spider which proceeded to slaughter me without remorse and then camp my corpse.

Ok, so I mentioned a bit about graphics.  This game is pretty dated as far as the graphics go.  If you can't look past that then you really won't enjoy what this gem of a game truly has to offer.  Being an all-around gamer I found this to be not so bad.  In fact, there are many aspects of the graphics that I actually really like.  Little details, like fish swimming in the water, are very nicely done.

The interface of this game will frustrate the hell out of a lot of the newer generation of gamers.  Most of your actions are done via right-click menus and require you to have certain items or tools "activated" before the right-click menu will give you the options your looking for.  For example, having a hand saw activated and right-clicking a log in your inventory will give you completely different crafting options than if you had a knife activated.  That said, once you get the hang of the interface you can actually see it's really well designed for the level of detail and openness this game offers.

It's hard to judge the world of this game, having not seen all of it yet myself and also knowing that you can use custom worlds with a little tweaking.  It seemed very "real", as if the map was created naturally rather than by a person at a computer.  The jist of it is that there are 3 kingoms on opposing sides of the map and they expand their territories as much as they can, eventually meeting each other and then... Well, that's open to whatever the players want do at that point.  They can be diplomatic and trade lands for other lands, they can war and attempt to take land from the other kingdoms, or they can just live peacefully with their current borders.  There are goals to the game, with "winning" being an option, but depending on what style of server you play on those goals can either be important or not.

Now we get to crafting.  This is where this game REALLY gets some major points.  The crafting system is incredibly indepth, as mentioned earlier.  It's so indepth that you can't actually craft a lump of metal, which you have already smelted, unless it's reheated to a "glowing" state.  In addition, the more indepth a crafted object is the more resources and crafting stages it requires.  Example, to build a guard tower you have to first build the base of the tower, which is easy.  Then you have to add 500 stone blocks (a crafted item), 500 clay, and 100 planks (a crafted item) before the tower is finished.   This is a HUGE task!  Another example would be a knife.  You can't simply place a lump of ore on a stick and call it a knife (lookin at you Minecraft).  You have to craft the knife blade out of metal, and then a handle from wood, and put the two together to finally make the knife.  Crafting materials and requirements seemed very logical, almost "real".  That seems to be the theme of this game, bring as much reality to it as you can, while not loosing the fact that it's a fantasy game.

In addition to crafting, the materials of the world didn't come in numbered items.  For example, if you picked up a rock you didn't have 1 rock.  You had so many kg of rock.  Each time you crafted something it took a portion of that rock to craft it.  You could also have many rocks, of various weights.  Some might be too small to craft an item with, some might be big enough to have leftover.  They could also be combined to merge their individual portions into one larger portion.  So you could have one rock that is 10kg and another that is 20kg, merge them together and get a 30kg rock.  The weight of items was very important to monitor, as your movement speed didn't just go from 100% to encumbered.  There were actually multiple stages to walking speed.  So carrying 40% of your maximum weight would actually have an impact on the speed you walked, again very realistic.

So getting down to the nitty gritty.  What is Wurm Unlimited?  Well, it's a very good MMO, in a fantasy setting, including a high detail of realism, that's been converted to home use.  If it's just you playing it you'll find the world very empty and a lot of things will be a very difficult challenge.  If it's you and a few friends there is quite a bit of enjoyment to be found, although the 3 kingdom aspect of the game will probably never be used.  If it's you and a dedicated server of 30+ players you might be able to experience all this game has to offer.

So do I recommend it?  This is where the difficulty is.  For a player such as myself, who loves a challenge and doesn't mind tedious grunt work to get a task done, this game is absolutely awesome.  For the newer generation of (spoiled) players who like to press one key and click one button to get stuff done this game will come across as boring and very hard to play.  Personally though I absolutely love this game for it's mix of realistic crafting, true sandbox environent, and RPG aspects.

So again, do I recommend it?  Oy...  It's extremely hard to decide.  If I was to look at this game 10 years ago, at it's current price, I'd think it was a hell of a deal.  Today, not so sure.  Personally I think $32 is fairly overpriced.  That said, I got it on the Steam Sale for $16 which is a much more reasonable cost.  So?

Yes... Yes, I recommend it.   ---- BUT ----  Only if you can get it on sale at 50% off it's $32 price tag.
